scenes.on_screen_action: Fast cut: Distracted Boyfriend meme (left: 'Neural net = black box' labeled girlfriend; boyfriend turning to 'CLIPS: assert → rule fires' labeled passing). Bold animated text zooms in. Quick camera push into a terminal window forming from the meme.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Want an expert system you can actually read and debug? Meet CLIPS — one assert, one fired rule. See it in 30 seconds.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Want predictable AI? (Hook)
Neural net = black box  — girlfriend
CLIPS: assert → rule fires  — passing
Hook: See one assert turn into a fired rule — CLIPS in 30s

scenes.on_screen_action: Expanding Brain / Galaxy Brain meme animation with three panels showing increasing clarity: 'If/else', 'Train ML', 'Rule-based CLIPS'. Overlay icons for facts, rules, objects. Quick label: 'Forward-chaining'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: CLIPS is a multiparadigm language: rule-based, object-oriented, and procedural. It uses forward-chaining — start with facts, apply rules, derive new facts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
CLIPS = rule-based + object-oriented + procedural
Forward-chaining: Facts → Rules → New Facts
Levels of reasoning:
  If/else → Train ML → Rule-based CLIPS

scenes.on_screen_action: Split-screen: left shows 'deftemplate' card, right shows terminal. Animated arrows show facts built from templates. Add small 'Confused by deftemplates?' sticker and a Surprised Pikachu pop when it 'clicks'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Facts are the building blocks. Use deftemplate to define a fact structure — a relation name and slots (like fields).
scenes.on_screen_text:
deftemplate = structure for facts
Example:
(deftemplate pet
  (slot name)
  (slot species)
  (slot hungry (default no)))

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal zoom: show asserting a fact. Animated keystrokes type the code. Little 'ping!' sound and a fact icon drops into a list labeled FACT-LIST.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Add facts with assert. You can also group initial facts with deffacts and push them in with reset.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Assert a fact:
(assert (pet (name "Fido") (species dog) (hungry yes)))

Group initial facts:
(deffacts initial
  (pet (name "Fido") (species dog) (hungry yes)))

Commands:
  reset  — clear & assert deffacts
  assert — add a fact

scenes.on_screen_action: Rule anatomy infographic: header, LHS conditional elements, RHS actions. Show a sample rule block on the right. Add a small 'Facts → Agenda → Fired rules' banner. Add Surprised Pikachu when rule fires.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Rules have a header, conditional elements on the left (LHS) that match facts, and actions on the right (RHS) that run when matched. Matching rules become activated and go on the agenda.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Rule structure:
(defrule <name>
  <LHS patterns>
  =>
  <RHS actions>)

Example:
(defrule feed-hungry-pet
  (pet (name ?n) (hungry yes))
  =>
  (printout t "Feeding " ?n crlf)
  (modify ?fact (hungry no)))

Pipeline: Facts → Agenda → Fired rules

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal demo: rapid-fire keystrokes run these commands. Show (watch facts) toggled on the left, assertion in the middle, and rule firing messages on the right. Use a small meme 'Mocking SpongeBob' bubble saying 'AI is a black box' crossed out.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Let's demo: turn on watch to see facts, assert a fact, run and watch the rule fire. Real-time debugging — no black box.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(watch facts)
(deffacts initial
  (pet (name "Fido") (species dog) (hungry yes)))
(reset)
(run)

Terminal output (example):
   => ASSERT: f-1 (pet ...)
   Activation: feed-hungry-pet
   => firing: feed-hungry-pet
   Feeding Fido

scenes.on_screen_action: Quick meme cut: Two Buttons sweating developer (Two Buttons meme). Left button shows 'Retrain huge model', right shows 'Write 3 CLIPS rules + assert'. Camera snaps to right button pressed with cheering sticker.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Bug in logic? Two choices: retrain a huge model, or write a few CLIPS rules and assert facts. Choose CLIPS — faster and debuggable.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Bug in logic? Two choices:
  Retrain huge model (pain)
  Write 3 CLIPS rules + assert (fast)
Choose CLIPS — demo in 30s

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal demonstration: show modify and retract commands. Animate a fact object changing color on modify and disappearing on retract. Add 'watch facts' messages showing ASSERT, MODIFY, RETRACT events.
scenes.dialogue_vo: You can change facts with modify and remove them with retract. watch will print assertions, modifications and retractions so you can trace state.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(assert (pet (name "Milo") (hungry yes)))
=> f-2
(modify f-2 (hungry no))
=> MODIFY: f-2
(retract f-2)
=> RETRACT: f-2

Debugging:
  (watch facts)  — print facts operations

scenes.on_screen_action: Educational overlay: show variables and wildcards with callouts. Code snippet highlighting ?name and $?rest. Animated matching lines linking variable names to values in a fact.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Variables let you capture values from facts. Use ?name for single slots and $?multi for multi-field matches. Wildcards let you match without caring about the value.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Variables & wildcards:
  ?name   — single-slot variable
  $?rest  — multi-field variable
Example pattern:
(pet (name ?n) (tags $?tags))
  Matches: ?n = "Fido", $?tags = (friendly brown)

scenes.on_screen_action: Meme montage: Drake Hotline Bling — top (Drake rejects) 'Retrain whole model', bottom (Drake approves) 'Assert + run in CLIPS'. Animated checklist ticks next to CLIPS advantages: readable rules, debug with watch, deterministic firing.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Don't retrain the world. Assert a fact, run CLIPS, watch the agenda, and fire the rule. It's transparent and controllable.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Drake:
  Retrain whole model — reject
  Assert + run in CLIPS — approve
Benefits:
  - Readable rules
  - Watchable facts
  - Predictable agenda

scenes.on_screen_action: Concise full example: show a tiny CLIPS program in a centered terminal, then show the run output appearing quickly. Use a progress bar labeled 'Facts → Agenda → Fire'. Add small 'No cap: you can debug this' tag.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Full mini program: deftemplate, deffacts, rule, reset, run — all together. Watch one assert turn into a fired rule.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Full mini program:
(deftemplate pet (slot name) (slot hungry (default no)))
(deffacts initial
  (pet (name "Fido") (hungry yes)))
(defrule feed
  (pet (name ?n) (hungry yes))
  => (printout t "Feeding " ?n crlf) (modify ?fact (hungry no)))

Commands:
reset
run

Output:
=> ASSERT: f-1 (pet ...)
=> firing: feed
Feeding Fido

scenes.on_screen_action: Closing shot: Mocking SpongeBob meme panel says 'AI is a black box' then flips to 'Hold my CLIPS — watch on'. Big bold CTA buttons: 'Follow for deftemplates deep-dive' and 'Try CLIPS now'. Quick flash of hooks list and final tagline.
scenes.dialogue_vo: That's CLIPS in a minute: facts, deftemplates, rules, agenda, run, reset, watch, assert, modify, retract. Want a deeper dive? Follow for a deftemplate deep-dive and a debugging walkthrough.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Recap: Facts, Deftemplates, Rules, Agenda, Run, Reset, Watch, Assert, Modify, Retract
Hooks:
  Want an expert system? Meet CLIPS — one assert, one fired rule.
  Debug CLIPS in 30s: use (watch facts)
Call to action:
  Follow for deftemplates & debugging
  Try CLIPS now — see facts → agenda → fired rules

voice_timing.text: Want an expert system you can actually read and debug? Meet CLIPS — one assert, one fired rule. See it in 30 seconds.
CLIPS is a multiparadigm language: rule-based, object-oriented, and procedural. It uses forward-chaining — start with facts, apply rules, derive new facts.
Facts are the building blocks. Use deftemplate to define a fact structure — a relation name and slots (like fields).
Add facts with assert. You can also group initial facts with deffacts and push them in with reset.
Rules have a header, conditional elements on the left (LHS) that match facts, and actions on the right (RHS) that run when matched. Matching rules become activated and go on the agenda.
Let's demo: turn on watch to see facts, assert a fact, run and watch the rule fire. Real-time debugging — no black box.
Bug in logic? Two choices: retrain a huge model, or write a few CLIPS rules and assert facts. Choose CLIPS — faster and debuggable.
You can change facts with modify and remove them with retract. watch will print assertions, modifications and retractions so you can trace state.
Variables let you capture values from facts. Use ?name for single slots and $?multi for multi-field matches. Wildcards let you match without caring about the value.
Don't retrain the world. Assert a fact, run CLIPS, watch the agenda, and fire the rule. It's transparent and controllable.
Full mini program: deftemplate, deffacts, rule, reset, run — all together. Watch one assert turn into a fired rule.
That's CLIPS in a minute: facts, deftemplates, rules, agenda, run, reset, watch, assert, modify, retract. Want a deeper dive? Follow for a deftemplate deep-dive and a debugging walkthrough.
